27
Classes and Class Hierarchy (II)
 Organize the classes into a hierarchical taxonomy by asking if by being an instance 
of one class, the object will necessarily (i.e., by definition) be an instance of some 
other class.
 If a class A is a superclass of class B, then every instance of B is also an 
instance of A
 Apple is a subclass of Fruit Æ Every apple is a fruit
 Red wines is a subclass of Wine Æ Every red wine is a wine
 Chianti wine is a subclass of Red wine  Æ Every Chianti wine is a red wine
 A single person is not a subclass of all persons
